content:
=== Game Rules ===
Game rules in natural language:
Here’s an overview in plain language:

1. Game Genre and Feel:
 • It’s much like a classic action-puzzle or platform-adventure game (think along the lines of Spelunky). You control an avatar in a level filled with obstacles, collectibles, and moving hazards. There’s an emphasis on exploration, careful movement, and using your tools wisely.

2. Core Mechanics:
 • Movement & Interaction: You control an "avatar" that can shoot a “sword” (or pickaxe) to interact with the environment. For instance, using the sword on dirt may “kill” or remove the dirt, letting you craft your path.
 • Collectibles: Diamonds are scattered about, each adding to your score when picked up. However, there’s a cap (limit=10) and a transformation twist—interactions between enemies (like butterflies and crabs) might even transform them into diamond resources.
 • Environmental Hazards: Boulders act like missiles that move slowly downward; they can hurt you if you’re hit from the wrong direction. Their physics are a bit “bouncy” (stepping back) when they run into fixed obstacles such as walls, dirt, or even other boulders.
 • Enemy Interactions: Besides standard “enemy” sprites, creatures like crabs, butterflies, and others wander randomly. They even interact with one another (for example, when a crab meets a butterfly, one might vanish or transform). Being caught in these encounters—especially if the interactions aren’t in your favor—can cost you points.

3. Objective and Win/Loss Conditions:
 • The Goal: You need to navigate your way through the level, collecting resources—especially diamonds—and reach an exit door.
 • Exitdoor Requirements: The exit door will “activate” (removing itself to signal level completion) only if you satisfy the specific condition regarding diamonds. In this case, when you touch the door, it checks if you’re carrying a certain amount (the rule “killIfOtherHasMore resource=diamond limit=9” suggests you must have nine or fewer diamonds or at least meet a particular diamond count requirement to exit safely).
 • Losing: You lose if your avatar is destroyed or if hazards (like falling boulders, mishandled enemy encounters, or other dangerous interactions) overwhelm you.
 • Winning: The level is cleared when the exit door is “used” under the right conditions (and then removed from play), meaning you’ve successfully met the objective.

4. Overall Strategy:
 • Explore Carefully: Survey the level layout to plan a path that avoids unnecessary risks such as falling boulders or tricky enemy clusters.
 • Manage Resources: Prioritize collecting diamonds to boost your score—but also be mindful of the door’s diamond check. This means you may need to strike a balance between gathering rewards and meeting the door’s requirements.
 • Use Your Sword Tactically: The sword isn’t just for attacking enemies—it may help you remove blocks of dirt or even clear obstacles. Identify opportunities where using it can eliminate threats or shortcut your progress.
 • Let the Environment Work for You: Since boulders and enemy interactions have predictable behaviors (boulders step back when colliding with walls or other fixed objects, enemies avoid obstacles similarly), use these tendencies to your advantage. You might, for example, lure an enemy into another enemy or trap to turn them into a resource (as seen when a butterfly turns into a diamond after an interaction with a crab).
 • Keep an Eye on Directions: Some interactions (like the “killIfFromAbove” rule) hint that attacking certain hazards from the right direction—such as landing on a boulder—could work in your favor (or at least reduce the damage).

In summary, treat the game as a blend of puzzles and action. Plan your movements, time your attacks, use environmental hazards cleverly, and always be mindful of resource counts and exit conditions. With careful exploration and strategic thinking, you can turn the tricks of the level into your advantage and safely exit to win the game.

You are an intelligent player playing a video game, and you have a friend provide you strategy. Interpret the state, rule, strategy and act accordingly. Notice that your avatar position is one of the most important information, if the position doesn't change from the last state, you need to analyze the state and make a different action from the last time.

=== Available Actions ===
0: ACTION_NIL
1: ACTION_USE
2: ACTION_LEFT
3: ACTION_RIGHT
4: ACTION_DOWN
5: ACTION_UP

=== Important Mechanics Notice ===
 In some games, directional actions (LEFT, RIGHT, UP, DOWN) may first cause the avatar to rotate toward the intended direction without immediately moving. If the avatar's position does not change after a directional action, it may indicate a rotation has occurred. To proceed, you must apply the directional action again after rotation. Always verify whether the avatar actually moved after each action. Please understand the rule and the interaction set first, then locate the item, finally choose a meaningful action towards the win and respond in the format: ``` Action:<action number> ```. Include one sentence of feedback on the action and your expectation to see if it aligns with the strategy. Notice, Action 0 will not reasult in any change in this game environment, and you may need to understand the level layout first to play the game. 

=== Sprite Mapping ===
avatar -> 'a'
background dirt -> '.'
background -> '-'
background exitdoor -> 'e'
background boulder -> 'o'
background diamond -> 'x'
background crab -> 'c'
background butterfly -> 'b'
boulder -> '@'
butterfly -> '#'
crab -> '$'
diamond -> '%'
dirt -> '&'
exitdoor -> '*'
wall -> 'b'
sword -> 'd'

Action:5

I'm moving UP from (2,6) toward the clear space at (1,6) to explore further while staying safe, and I expect this will advance my position cleanly per our strategy.
